> This brings up a question that I've been pondering: Given a test T, which of
> the following two choices is more desirable?
>    o Enable profiling for T by specifying some preference and let the
> execution framework do the rest.
>    o Enable profiling for T by coding a new test Tp that decorates T with
> profiling. When you want to run T with profiling you run Tp. When you want
> to run T without it you just run T. This is very similar to the way
> JUnitPerf works.


The question you have to ask yourself is where you want to add 
complexity.  If you want the user to do the work -> 2nd proposition, 
otherwise the 1st is IMHO better.

I like to separate "writing tests" from "running tests" so IMO profiling 
is simply another way to run your tests -> 1st proposition.

Furthermore, the work of profiling is done by your runner (with Tp or T 
+ special runner) in every case so keep things as simple as possible for 
the user and do all the work -> 1st proposition.

-Vladimir
